did.unittitle: Paul Ehrlich papers

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Paul Ehrlich, 1854-1915, physician and scientist, Berlin and Frankfurt, Germany. Founder of hematology, pioneer and major contributor to the fields of histochemistry and immunology. Famous for his development of chemotherapy (arsphenamine - 606) for syphilis. Nobel Laureate in physiology or medicine in 1908, jointly with Elie Metchnikoff for their studies in immunity.
Biographical Information: 1854 - Born March 14 in Strehlen, Silesia.
1872 - Graduated from St. Maria Magdalena Gymnasium in Breslau.
1878 - M.D. from the University of Leipzig, after studies at the Universities of Breslau, Strassburg and Freiburg.
1878-1888 - Assistant physician, later senior physician at the Charité Hospital in Berlin, director Professor von Frerichs.
1888/1889 - After contracting tuberculosis cured in Italy and Egypt.
1889 - Established a small private research laboratory in Berlin.
1890 - Appointment in the Robert Koch Institute for Infectious Diseases in Berlin.
1896 - Appointed director of the new State Institute for Serum Research and Serum Control in Steglitz, a suburb of Berlin.
1898 - This institute moved to Frankfurt and was expanded and renamed: The Institute for Experimental Therapy.
1906 - The Georg-Speyer wing for chemotherapeutical research was added with the private financial help of Mrs. Franzisca.
1908 - Nobel Prize in physiology and medicine.
1911 - Received the state rank of "Wirklicher Geheimer Rath" with the title of Excellency.
1914 - Named "Ordentlicher Professor" at the newly founded University of Frankfurt.
1915 - August 20, died in Bad Homburg and is buried in the Jewish Cemetery in Frankfurt.
Honorary Degrees: 1904 - University of Chicago, LL.D. 1907 - University of Oxford, D.C.L. 1911 - University of Athens, Dr. phil. h.c. 1911 - University of Breslau, Dr. med. h.c.

Awards: 1887 - Senckenberg Naturforschende Gesellschaft, Frankfurt a.M. Tiedemann Prize. 1903 - The Prussian Great-Golden Medal of Science. 1906 - Prize of Honor at the XVth International Congress of Medicine at Lisbon. 1908 - Nobel Prize. 1911 - Liebig Medal, Society of German Chemists. 1914 - Cameron Prize of Edinburgh.
Orders: Bavaria: Member of the Bavarian Maximilian Order.
Denmark: Commander Cross of the Dannebrog Order, Second Class.
Japan: Order of the Rising Sun, Third Degree.
Norway: Commander Cross of the Royal Norwegian St. Olaf Order, Second Degree.

Venezuela: Order of the Bust of Bolivar, Second Degree, with Precious Stones

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Ehrlich papers, a special collection of the Rockefeller University, consists of copy books and their typescripts, laboratory notes, correspondence, photographs, books, diplomas, obituary material and memorabilia. There is very little incoming correspondence in this collection, although a synopsis of about 450 letters is available. This synopsis may have been prepared by Martha Marquardt, Paul Ehrlich's secretary for many years. Many original letters by Paul Ehrlich, both handwritten and typed, with his signature are part of this collection. These letters seem to have been collected by the recipients and returned to Mrs. Ehrlich after her husband's death. Mrs. Ehrlich may also have requested reminiscences about her husband by his friends and colleagues which she collected, hoping to yield suitable material for a biography at a later time.

The collection was given by the grandsons of Paul Ehrlich, Hans and Günther Schwerin, with the aim to establish a central Paul Ehrlich archive, since much of the material was dispersed during the war years. Mr. Günther Schwerin located the copy books right after the war in Germany and sent them and other material to the Wellcome Institute for the History of Medicine in London for safekeeping. Miss Marquardt, after having spent the war years in France, went to London and transcribed the copy books, since Ehrlich's handwriting is very hard to read and she was one of the few people who could do so. At that time Dr. F. Himmelweit, London, prepared the Collected Papers of Paul Ehrlich in four volumes. Pergamon Press published three volumes in 1960 (the fourth was never published) with and introduction by Sir Henry Dale, a friend and colleague of Paul Ehrlich.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The papers of Paul Ehrlich were deposited with The Rockefeller University Archives on November 1978 by Mr. Günther Schwerin.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

did.unittitle: Copy Books and Transcripts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy-books: there are 47 bound volumes of copies of correspondence, laboratory notes and instructions, as well as laboratory protocols. Each book has about 500 pages; many of these are copies of handwritten notes and letters by Paul Ehrlich, the other pages are copies of typewritten letters with Ehrlich's signature. Typescript: Martha Marquardt transcribed the handwritten pages and made four copies (in a few cases six copies). Three copies are in this collection, the fourth remained at the Wellcome Institute, London. Miss Marquardt divided the labeled copy-books in Series I-VI, since they overlap in time and contain copies of varying material.
Series I: labeled: Copir Buch, are copies of correspondence
Series II: Zettel Buch, are copies of "Blöcke" (i.e. laboratory instruction written on cardboard)
Series III: Carcinom, are copies of notes about cancer research
Series IV: Direcktor Ehrlich, are copies of laboratory protocol notes to co-workers and some correspondence
Series V: Direcktor Ehrlich, are copies of correspondence and some "Blöcke"
Series VI: Speyer-Haus, are copies of "Blöcke", laboratory instructions and protocol notes
Each box contains the copy-book and three copies of the typescripts. Where there are more copies, they are stored in boxes labeled with an "A".

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged in chronological order and by Series #.

Engagement time letters between Paul Ehrlich and Hedwig Pinkus

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Covering the period of February 1883 to August 1883. Paul and Hedwig married on Tuesday, August 14, 1883.

There are 106 handwritten letters by Paul Ehrlich to Hedwig Pinkus and 103 by Hedwig to Paul. Two so-called "Brautbriefe" written by Paul on February 25 and 27, 1883 are of special interest. The February 25 letter was sent by Ehrlich's daughters in 1955 to Sir Henry Dale as a gift and memento. This letter was later sold and is therefore not part of this collection in the original; only a photo copy is available. There are 3 typescript copies of these 2 letters; none of the others have been transcribed.

Box No. 48 contains Hedwig's letters and Box No. 49 contains Paul's. There are some related letters by Hedwig's parents and wedding invitations in Box No. 48. Many of these letters have the original envelopes and stamps.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The letters are in chronological order but not integrated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 2 tapes of speeches given at a dinner in honor for Hedwig Ehrlich, October 1941 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. One tape contains a radio address and dinner speech by Hedwig Ehrlich. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact a RAC archivist for further instruction.

did.unittitle: Syphilis and Salvarsan

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Access copy currently unavailable. Please contact an RAC archivist for further instruction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A brief introduction to the early prognosis and treatment methods for syphilis. Medical names, equipment, and methods are discussed. Part of the Principles of Genetics Lecture Series.
